intro: Sida multicaulis, commonly known as the hairy sida, is an annual herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters and has alternate, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often hairy. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in open areas such as roadsides and fields. Sida multicaulis is characterized by its simple, branching stems and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
